Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: PPER: Enable Crowdsourcing in Microbial Water Quality Monitoring in Water Distribution Networks

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Microbial contamination of drinking water within the distribution networks can occur at unspecified locations, at unspecified times, and due to diverse reasons, causing significant public health problems and uncertainties. The final critical control point against microbial contamination within the water distribution networks is at the tap where human water consumption occurs, yet water quality monitoring at the tap represents a major operational challenge to water utilities. This challenging problem, however, is an excellent opportunity for involving and motivating the public in water quality engineering research, as water customers are perfectly situated and often interested and motivated in knowing water microbial quality at their own homes. If enabling, low-cost tools are available to water customers, this could become an excellent example of how citizen science can be cultivated and harnessed to solve a complex and otherwise intractable water quality engineering problem. Two major technology gaps for involving citizens in this crowdsourcing approach include: (1) collecting reliable water microbial quality data within households and low-cost tools, and (2) encouraging and facilitating voluntary and efficient data sharing. The research goal of this project is to enable crowdsourcing by specifically and effectively addressing these two technology gaps.

This project uses an iterative citizen consultation process to optimize a crowdsourcing approach that enables low-cost and high-quality measurements of total coliform and E. coli in drinking water samples by water consumers. Specifically, a commonly used EPA method is being adopted and modified for home implementation using commonly available household tools. The two research objectives are (1) to define, test, and optimize the proposed crowdsourcing approach, and (2) to investigate the feasibility of using an integrated device for one-step water sample collection and subsequent processing. The project involves a large group of undergraduate students at a largely commuter campus with diverse backgrounds as citizen scientists. Their participation not only provides feedback to the design, test, and optimization of the crowdsourcing approach, but also provides the participants with a great opportunity to understand the importance and complexity of water quality data collection in the distribution networks.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Since microbial contaminants in drinking water can cause acute public health problems, tremendous efforts have been made to protect water sources and to treat and test the microbial quality of drinking water at treatment plants. In spite of these upstream efforts, drinking water quality can still degrade when it flows the distribution networks, undergoes post-tap treatments (e.g. home water filters), and during storage (e.g. personal water containers) before consumption. Drinking water quality monitoring at these final steps before human consumption is practically and economically infeasible for water utilities to implement, and there has been limited data on associated health risk. On the other hand, water customers are perfectly positioned in such data collection and usually interested and motivated in knowing the microbial quality of their drinking water, creating a much-needed practical and public impetus for citizen science participation and engagement.

 

This project aimed to engage the general public in collecting drinking water samples of their concerns to understand the drinking water quality before consumption. The project recruited citizen science participants, conducted educational workshops, organized drinking water sampling, completed analyses of the collected samples, and provided results and feedbacks to the participants. After obtaining an Institutional Review Board approval, an online survey was conducted to recruit potential participants, from which 30 participants were selected. Two sessions of workshops were conducted to introduce the citizen science project participants to how drinking water is sourced and treated, how drinking water quality is monitored, and the basics of water sampling processes and protocols. The project then completed a drinking water sampling campaign by the citizen science project participants, which was primarily driven by the participants who themselves decided on the types and locations of drinking water samples.

 

The water samples collected by the citizen science project participants were diverse, ranging from home water taps, drinking fountain, to personal water bottles. The samples were analyzed for total coliforms and Escherichia coli per EPA’s Method 1604 and overall microbial community structures through 16S rRNA gene amplicon sequencing. Bioinformatic analyses was conducted to reveal the microbial composition of the various types of samples, including tap water, drinking fountain, personal container, and home filtered water samples. The water samples collected by citizen science project participants from private home water taps and public drinking fountains in Honolulu were generally of high quality according to E. coli and Total Coliforms enumeration. However, personal containers for drinking water generally showed reduced water quality as indicated by higher counts of E. coli and total coliforms, indicating the importance of routinely cleaning and maintaining these devices. Overall, the research demonstrated the feasibility of engaging the general public to monitor drinking water quality and identified the importance of drinking water quality in personal water containers used for water storage.
